Byzantine-Robust Variance-Reduced Federated Learning over Distributed Non-i.i.d. Data

Jie Peng, Zhaoxian Wu, Qing Ling, and Tianyi Chen Jie Peng, Zhaoxian Wu and Qing Ling are with the School of Computer Science and Engineering, the Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Computational Science, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou 510006, China, and also with the Pazhou Lab, Guangzhou 510335, China. The work of Qing Ling is supported in part by National Natural Science Foundation of China under grant 61973324, Guangdong Basic and Applied Basic Research Foundation under grant 2021B1515020094, and Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Computational Science, Sun Yat-Sen University under grant 2020B1212060032. (e-mail: pengj95@mail2.sysu.edu.cn; wuzhx23@mail2.sysu.edu.cn; lingqing556@mail.sysu.edu.cn).Tianyi Chen is with the Department of Electrical, Computer, and Systems Engineering, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY 12180 USA (e-mail: chent18@rpi.edu).
Abstract

We consider the federated learning problem where data on workers are not independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.). During the learning process, an unknown number of Byzantine workers may send malicious messages to the central node, leading to remarkable learning error. Most of the Byzantine-robust methods address this issue by using robust aggregation rules to aggregate the received messages, but rely on the assumption that all the regular workers have i.i.d. data, which is not the case in many federated learning applications. In light of the significance of reducing stochastic gradient noise for mitigating the effect of Byzantine attacks, we use a resampling strategy to reduce the impact of both inner variation (that describes the sample heterogeneity on every regular worker) and outer variation (that describes the sample heterogeneity among the regular workers), along with a stochastic average gradient algorithm to gradually eliminate the inner variation. The variance-reduced messages are then aggregated with a robust geometric median operator. We prove that the proposed method reaches a neighborhood of the optimal solution at a linear convergence rate and the learning error is determined by the number of Byzantine workers. Numerical experiments corroborate the theoretical results and show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-arts in the non-i.i.d. setting.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, distributed optimization, variance reduction, non-i.i.d. data, Byzantine attacks

I Introduction

With the rapid increase of data volume and computing power, the past decades have witnessed the explosive development of machine learning. However, many machine learning methods require a central server or a cloud to collect data from various owners and train models in a centralized manner, leading to serious privacy concerns. To address this issue, federated learning keeps data private at their owners and carries out machine learning tasks locally [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. Every data owner (called worker thereafter) performs local computation based on its local data and sends the results (such as local models, gradients, stochastic gradients, etc) to the central server. The central server (called central node thereafter) aggregates the results received from the workers and updates the global model.

Nevertheless, the distributed nature of federated learning makes it vulnerable to attacks [4]. Due to the heterogeneity of federated learning systems, workers are not all reliable. Some workers might be malfunctioning or even adversarial, and send malicious messages to the central node. This paper considers the classical Byzantine attack model [7], where an unknown number of Byzantine workers are omniscient, collude with each other, and send arbitrary malicious messages. Moreover, the identities of Byzantine workers are unknown to the central node. Misled by the Byzantine workers, the aggregation at the central node is problematic, such that the federated learning method may converge to an unsatisfactory model or even diverge. For instance, the popular distributed stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method fails at presence of Byzantine attacks from a single worker [8].

Most of the Byzantine-robust distributed methods modify distributed SGD to handle Byzantine attacks, by replacing mean aggregation with robust aggregation at the central node [9, 10, 11]. When the data on the workers are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) and the local cost functions are in the same form, stochastic gradients computed at the same point are i.i.d. too. Therefore, various robust aggregation rules, such as geometric median [8], can be applied to alleviate the effect of statistically biased messages sent by Byzantine workers. Unfortunately, the data on the workers are often non-i.i.d. in federated learning applications [12, 13]. Thus, the messages sent by the regular workers are no longer i.i.d. such that handling Byzantine attacks becomes more challenging.

I-A Our contributions

In the Byzantine-robust federated learning setting, this paper considers the distributed finite-sum minimization problem when the workers have non-i.i.d. data. Our contributions are summarized as follows.

C1) In light of the significance of reducing stochastic gradient noise for mitigating the effect of Byzantine attacks, we propose a Byzantine-robust variance-reduced SGD method, using a resampling strategy to reduce the impact of both inner variation (that describes the sample heterogeneity on every regular worker) and outer variation (that describes the sample heterogeneity among the regular workers), while a stochastic average gradient algorithm (SAGA) to fully eliminate the inner variation. The variance-reduced messages are then aggregated with a robust geometric median operator.

C2) We prove that the proposed method reaches a neighborhood of the optimal solution at a linear convergence rate, and the learning error is explicitly determined by the number of Byzantine workers.

C3) We conduct numerical experiments on convex and nonconvex federated learning problems and in i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. settings. The experimental results corroborate the theoretical findings and show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-arts, especially in the non-i.i.d. setting.

I-B Related works

Federated learning, in a nutshell, belongs to the category of distributed optimization, for which there are extensive works, ranging from machine learning, signal processing to system control. For example, [14] proposes a projected primal-dual method to solve the distributed constrained nonsmooth convex optimization problem. Aiming at the distributed time-varying formation problem, [15] proposes a distributed framework with the help of time-varying optimization methods. Below we focus on the related works in Byzantine-robustness of distributed algorithms, especially those handling non-i.i.d. data.

Byzantine-robust distributed machine learning has attracted much attention in recent years. In distributed SGD, the central node aggregates messages received from the workers by taking average and uses the mean as aggregated gradient direction. The mean aggregation, however, is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks. Existing Byzantine-robust distributed methods mostly extend the distributed SGD with robust aggregation rules, such as geometric median [8], normalized aggregation [16], coordinate-wise median [17], coordinate-wise trimmed mean [17], Krum [18], multi-Krum [18], Bulyan [19], to name a few. Algorithms leveraging second-order information has also be considered in [20]. Another approach is to detect and discard outliers from the received messages [21, 22, 23]. When the received stochastic gradients from the regular workers satisfy the i.i.d. assumption, the statistically different malicious messages from the Byzantine workers can be detected and discarded, or their negative effect can be alleviated by robust aggregation rules. For network anomaly detection in distributed online optimization, [24] proposes a distributed one-class support vector machine method.

Aiming at Byzantine-robustness with distributed non-i.i.d. data, [25] proposes a robust stochastic aggregation method that employs model aggregation rather than stochastic gradient aggregation. Forced by the introduced consensus constraints, the regular workers and the central node shall reach consensus on their local models, no matter the local data are i.i.d. or not. [26] also imposes asymptotic consensus between the regular workers and the central node, and proposes a Byzantine-robust proximal stochastic gradient method. [27] divides the cost functions of the workers into several clusters, such that within each cluster the i.i.d. assumption approximately holds. Then robust aggregation can be applied within each cluster. [28] introduces a resampling strategy to reduce the heterogeneity of the received messages in the non-i.i.d. setting.

In both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. settings, variance of the messages sent by the regular workers plays a critical role to Byzantine-robustness. Larger variance means that the malicious messages are harder to distinguish. Theoretically, the variance can be classified into inner variation that describes the sample heterogeneity on every regular worker and outer variation that describes the sample heterogeneity among the regular workers. In the i.i.d. setting the inner variation often dominates, while in the non-i.i.d. setting the outer variation can be large. [29] and its extended version [30] use SAGA to correct the stochastic gradients and aggregate the corrected stochastic gradients with geometric median. It has been proven that the impact of inner variation is fully eliminated from the learning error. [31] combines stochastic variance-reduced gradient (SVRG) with robust aggregation to solve distributed non-convex problems. [32] proves that the momentum method can reduce the variance of the stochastic gradients for the regular workers relative to their norm, and is thus helpful to Byzantine-robustness. [33] also claims that applying the momentum method can reduce the variance and enhance Byzantine-robustness. The resampling strategy used in [28] is able to reduce the impact of inner and outer variations simultaneously.

The work of this paper is closely related to [30] and [28], but not a simple combination of them. First, the theme of [30] is to investigate the importance of variance reduction to Byzantine-robustness for i.i.d. data, while this work considers non-i.i.d. data. [28] studies reducing the impact of inner and outer variations by resampling, but is unable to eliminate the impact of inner variation. Second, the theoretical analysis is more difficult than that in [30] and [28] because of the entanglement of variance reduction and resampling. We will highlight the differences of our lemmas and theorems in Section IV.

II Problem Formulation and Preliminaries

Consider a federated learning system consisting of one central node and W:=R+Bassign𝑊𝑅𝐵W:=R+B workers, among which R𝑅R workers are regular and B𝐵B workers are Byzantine. However, the numbers and identities of Byzantine workers are unknown to the central node. During the learning process, the Byzantine workers can collude to send arbitrary malicious messages to the central node [7]. Denote the sets of regular and Byzantine workers as ℛℛ\mathcal{R} and ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, respectively, with R=|ℛ|𝑅ℛR=|\mathcal{R}| and B=|ℬ|𝐵ℬB=|\mathcal{B}|. Denote 𝒲:=ℛ∪ℬ={1,⋯,W}assign𝒲ℛℬ1⋯𝑊\mathcal{W}:=\mathcal{R}\cup\mathcal{B}=\{1,\cdots,W\} as the set of all workers. The goal is to find an optimal solution to the finite-sum minimization problem

x∗=arg⁡minx⁡f​(x):=1R​∑w∈ℛfw​(x),superscript𝑥subscript𝑥𝑓𝑥assign1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛsubscript𝑓𝑤𝑥\displaystyle x^{*}=\arg\min_{x}f(x):=\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}f_{w}(x), (1)

with

fw​(x):=1J​∑j=1Jfw,j​(x).assignsubscript𝑓𝑤𝑥1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝑓𝑤𝑗𝑥\displaystyle f_{w}(x):=\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}f_{w,j}(x). (2)

Here x∈ℝp𝑥superscriptℝ𝑝x\in\mathbb{R}^{p} is the optimization variable, and fw​(x)subscript𝑓𝑤𝑥f_{w}(x) is the local cost function of regular worker w𝑤w averaging the costs fw,j​(x)subscript𝑓𝑤𝑗𝑥f_{w,j}(x) of J𝐽J samples. The samples are not necessarily i.i.d. across the regular workers. This finite-sum minimization form arises in many federated learning applications [3].

When the Byzantine workers are absent, distributed SGD [34] is a popular method to solve (1). The update of distributed SGD is given by

xk+1=xk−γ⋅1W​∑w=1Wfw,iwk′​(xk),superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝛾1𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑊subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘\displaystyle x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\cdot\frac{1}{W}\sum_{w=1}^{W}f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k}), (3)

where γ𝛾\gamma is the step size and iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k} is the sample index chosen by worker w𝑤w at time k𝑘k. Upon receiving xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} from the central node, every worker w𝑤w computes a stochastic gradient fw,iwk′​(xk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k}) and returns it to the central node. The central node then averages the received stochastic gradients and updates xk+1superscript𝑥𝑘1x^{k+1}. However, distributed SGD is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks. Even there is only one Byzantine worker, it can replace the true stochastic gradient with a malicious message, such that the average at the central node becomes zero or infinitely large [9].

Geometric median. To address this issue, most of the Byzantine-robust methods aggregate the received messages with robust aggregation rules. One popular approach is geometric median [8]. To be specific, define gwksuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘g_{w}^{k} as the message sent by worker w𝑤w at time k𝑘k to the central node, given by

gwk={fw,iwk′​(xk),w∈ℛ,∗,w∈ℬ.\displaystyle g_{w}^{k}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k}),&&w\in\mathcal{R},\\ &*,&&w\in\mathcal{B}.\end{aligned}\right. (4)

When w𝑤w is a regular worker, it sends the true stochastic gradient fw,iwk′​(xk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k}). Otherwise when w𝑤w is a Byzantine worker, it sends an arbitrary message denoted by ∗*. Upon receiving all the messages, the central node calculates the geometric median of {gwk,w∈𝒲}superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\{g_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}, which is

geomed​({gwk,w∈𝒲}):=arg⁡ming​∑w=1W‖g−gwk‖2.assigngeomedsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲subscript𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑊subscriptnorm𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘2\displaystyle\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{g_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right):=\arg\min_{g}\sum_{w=1}^{W}\|g-g_{w}^{k}\|_{2}. (5)

Then, the central node updates xk+1superscript𝑥𝑘1x^{k+1} by replacing the average in (3) with the geometric median, as

xk+1=xk−γ⋅geomed​({gwk,w∈𝒲}).superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝛾geomedsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\displaystyle x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\cdot\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{g_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right). (6)

It has been proved that when the regular workers have i.i.d. data, incorporating distributed SGD and geometric median allows us to tolerate Byzantine attacks when less than half of the workers are malicious, namely, B<W2𝐵𝑊2B<\frac{W}{2} [8]. However, when the regular workers have non-i.i.d. data, simply combining geometric median with distributed SGD is unable to defend against Byzantine attacks [25].

Why large variance hurts? To understand the importance of variance reduction to robust aggregation, we review the following concentration property of geometric median from [30, Lemma 1].

Property 1.

Let {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} be a set of random vectors. It holds when B<W2𝐵𝑊2B<\frac{W}{2} that

𝔼​‖geomed​({zw,w∈𝒲})−z¯‖2𝔼superscriptnormgeomedsubscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲¯𝑧2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right)-\bar{z}\|^{2} (7)
≤\displaystyle\leq Cα2R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​‖zw−𝔼​zw‖2+Cα2R​∑w∈ℛ‖𝔼​zw−z¯‖2,superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑧𝑤𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2𝑅subscript𝑤ℛsuperscriptnorm𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤¯𝑧2\displaystyle\frac{C_{\alpha}^{2}}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}{\mathbb{E}\|z_{w}-\mathbb{E}z_{w}\|^{2}}+\frac{C_{\alpha}^{2}}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}{\|\mathbb{E}z_{w}-\bar{z}\|^{2}},

where z¯:=1R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​zwassign¯𝑧1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤\bar{z}:=\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\mathbb{E}z_{w}, α:=BWassign𝛼𝐵𝑊\alpha:=\frac{B}{W}, Cα:=2−2​α1−2​αassignsubscript𝐶𝛼22𝛼12𝛼C_{\alpha}:=\frac{2-2\alpha}{1-2\alpha}, and 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} is taken over the random vectors.

Suppose zw=gwksubscript𝑧𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘z_{w}=g_{w}^{k} as defined (4), such that zwsubscript𝑧𝑤z_{w} is the true stochastic gradient when w𝑤w is regular, and an arbitrary malicious message when w𝑤w is Byzantine. The left-hand side of (7) denotes the mean-square error of the geometric median relative to the average of the true stochastic gradients. The right-hand side of (7) contains two terms. The first term now refers to the cross-sample variance (a.k.a. inner variation), while the second term refers to the cross-worker variance (a.k.a. outer variation). When either the inner variation or the outer variation is large, the geometric median aggregation yields a poor direction that eventually leads to large learning error, as illustrated in Fig. 1. This fact motivates Byrd-SAGA [29, 30]. It has been shown in [29, 30] that SAGA effectively eliminates the inner variation, i.e., the first term at the right-hand side of (7). However, for the non-i.i.d. case, the second term at the right-hand side of (7) can be large and still deteriorate the performance of robust aggregation.

III Algorithm Development

In light of the fact that the messages with large variance affect the robust aggregation performance, we propose to simultaneously reduce the inner and outer variations so as to achieve better performance in the non-i.i.d. setting. Specifically, we use the variance-reduced stochastic gradients at the worker side to gradually eliminate the inner variation, and use a resample-then-aggregate strategy at the central node to reduce outer variation.

Our proposed method is described as follows. At time k𝑘k, the central node broadcasts its current variable xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} to all the workers. Instead of sending the stochastic gradients to the central node, the regular workers send the corrected, variance-reduced stochastic gradients. To be specific, every regular worker stores the most recent stochastic gradient for every of its samples. When regular worker w𝑤w selects the sample index iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k} at time k𝑘k, the corrected stochastic gradient is

fw,iwk′​(xk)−fw,iwk′​(ϕw,iwkk)+1J​∑j=1Jfw,j′​(ϕw,jk),subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘𝑘1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤𝑗𝑘\displaystyle f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k})-f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(\phi_{w,i_{w}^{k}}^{k})+\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}f^{\prime}_{w,j}(\phi_{w,j}^{k}), (8)

where

ϕw,jk+1={ϕw,jk,j≠iwk,xk,j=iwk.\displaystyle\phi_{w,j}^{k+1}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &\phi_{w,j}^{k},&&j\neq i_{w}^{k},\\ &x^{k},&&j=i_{w}^{k}.\end{aligned}\right. (9)

That is, the stochastic gradient fw,iwk′​(xk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k}) is corrected by first subtracting the previously stored stochastic gradient fw,iwk′​(ϕw,iwkk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘𝑘f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(\phi_{w,i_{w}^{k}}^{k}) for sample iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k}, and then adding the average of all the stored stochastic gradients fw,j′​(ϕw,jk)subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤𝑗superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤𝑗𝑘f^{\prime}_{w,j}(\phi_{w,j}^{k}). At time k𝑘k, denote vwksuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘v_{w}^{k} as the corrected stochastic gradient if w𝑤w is regular and an arbitrary message ∗* if w𝑤w is Byzantine, given by

vwk={fw,iwk′​(xk)−fw,iwk′​(ϕw,iwkk)+1J​∑j=1Jfw,j′​(ϕw,jk),w∈ℛ,∗,w∈ℬ.\displaystyle\!\!\!\!v_{w}^{k}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k})-f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(\phi_{w,i_{w}^{k}}^{k})&&\\ &\hskip 30.00005pt+\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}f^{\prime}_{w,j}(\phi_{w,j}^{k}),&&w\in\mathcal{R},\\ &*,&&w\in\mathcal{B}.\end{aligned}\right. (10)

Building upon [28], we leverage a resample-then-aggregate strategy to reduce the outer variation in the non-i.i.d. case. After receiving the messages {vwk,w∈𝒲}superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\{v_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\} from all the workers, the central node takes W𝑊W rounds of sampling, and uniformly at random samples s𝑠s messages at every round. The W𝑊W rounds of sampling follows sampling with s𝑠s-replacement mechanism: when one message has been sampled for s𝑠s times, it will not be sampled again. At the end of each round w𝑤w, the central node averages the s𝑠s sampled messages to calculate the new message v~wksuperscriptsubscript~𝑣𝑤𝑘\tilde{v}_{w}^{k}. See a summary in Algorithm 1.

We denote this resampling procedure with s𝑠s-replacement as

{v~wk,w∈𝒲}=𝐑𝐒​({vwk,w∈𝒲},s).superscriptsubscript~𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲𝐑𝐒superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲𝑠\displaystyle\{\tilde{v}_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}=\mathbf{RS}\left(\{v_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\},s\right). (11)

Compared to the original messages {vwk,w∈𝒲}superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\{v_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}, the new messages {v~wk,w∈𝒲}superscriptsubscript~𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\{\tilde{v}_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\} have smaller variance due to the averaging step. In addition, at most s​B𝑠𝐵sB new messages are contaminated by the malicious messages {vwk,w∈ℬ}superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤ℬ\{v_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{B}\}, and the variance of uncontaminated new messages is also smaller than that of {vwk,w∈ℛ}superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤ℛ\{v_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{R}\}. Fig. 2 gives a deterministic example, showing that resampling indeed reduces the outer variation. For the stochastic case, the inner variation is reduced too.

Finally, the central node updates the variable from

xk+1=xk−γ⋅geomed​({v~wk,w∈𝒲}).superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝛾geomedsuperscriptsubscript~𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\displaystyle x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\cdot\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{\tilde{v}_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right). (12)

See a summary of our proposed method in Algorithm 2.

IV Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we theoretically analyze the performance of the proposed method, as well as investigate the effect of reducing the inner and outer variations on robust aggregation.

IV-A Assumptions

We start from introducing three assumptions on the sample costs {fw,j,w∈ℛ,j=1,⋯,J}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑤𝑗𝑤ℛ𝑗1⋯𝐽\{f_{w,j},w\in\mathcal{R},j=1,\cdots,J\}.

Assumption 1.

(Strong convexity and Lipschitz continuous gradients) The function f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-strong convex and has L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous gradients. Namely, for any x,y∈ℝp𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑝x,y\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}, it holds that

f​(y)≥f​(x)+⟨f′​(x),y−x⟩+μ2​‖y−x‖2,𝑓𝑦𝑓𝑥superscript𝑓′𝑥𝑦𝑥𝜇2superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle f(y)\geq f(x)+\langle f^{\prime}(x),y-x\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}, (13)

and

‖f′​(y)−f′​(x)‖≤L​‖y−x‖.normsuperscript𝑓′𝑦superscript𝑓′𝑥𝐿norm𝑦𝑥\displaystyle\|f^{\prime}(y)-f^{\prime}(x)\|\leq L\|y-x\|. (14)
Assumption 2.

(Bounded outer variation) For any x∈ℝp𝑥superscriptℝ𝑝x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}, the variation of the local gradients at the regular workers with respect to the global gradient is upper-bounded by

1R​∑w∈ℛ‖fw′​(x)−f′​(x)‖2≤δ2.1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤𝑥superscript𝑓′𝑥2superscript𝛿2\displaystyle\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\|f^{\prime}_{w}(x)-f^{\prime}(x)\|^{2}\leq\delta^{2}. (15)
Assumption 3.

(Bounded inner variation) For every regular worker w∈ℛ𝑤ℛw\in\mathcal{R} and any x∈ℝp𝑥superscriptℝ𝑝x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}, the variation of its stochastic gradients with respect to its local gradient is upper-bounded by

𝔼​‖fw,iwk′​(x)−fw′​(x)‖2≤σ2,∀w∈ℛ.formulae-sequence𝔼superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤𝑥2superscript𝜎2for-all𝑤ℛ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x)-f^{\prime}_{w}(x)\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2},~{}\forall w\in\mathcal{R}. (16)

Here we use 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} to denote the expectation with respect to all random variables iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k}.

Assumption 1 is standard for analyzing distributed learning algorithms. Assumptions 2 and 3 bound the inner variation that describes the sample heterogeneity on every regular worker and the outer variation that describes the sample heterogeneity among the regular workers, respectively. When all the samples at the regular workers are identical, both the inner variation and the outer variation are zero. When the distributed data are i.i.d. the inner variation is often larger than the outer variation, while for the non-i.i.d. case the outer variation usually dominates.

IV-B Concentration properties

Interestingly, augmented with the resampling strategy, geometric median shows better dependency on both the inner variation and the outer variation than that without resampling (as shown in Property 1). We give the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

Let {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} be a subset of random vectors distributed in a normed vector space and the random vectors in {zw,w∈ℛ}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤ℛ\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{R}\} are independent. Generate from {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} a new set {z~w,w∈𝒲}subscript~𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{\tilde{z}_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} using the resampling strategy with s𝑠s-replacement. It holds when B<W2​s𝐵𝑊2𝑠B<\frac{W}{2s} that

𝔼​‖geomed​({z~w,w∈𝒲})−z¯‖2𝔼superscriptnormgeomedsubscript~𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲¯𝑧2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{\tilde{z}_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right)-\bar{z}\|^{2} (17)
≤\displaystyle\leq (d+1−dR)​Cs​α2R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​‖zw−𝔼​zw‖2𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑧𝑤𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤2\displaystyle\left(d+\frac{1-d}{R}\right)\frac{C_{s\alpha}^{2}}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}{\mathbb{E}\|z_{w}-\mathbb{E}z_{w}\|^{2}}
+d​Cs​α2R​∑w∈ℛ‖𝔼​zw−z¯‖2,𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2𝑅subscript𝑤ℛsuperscriptnorm𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤¯𝑧2\displaystyle+\frac{dC_{s\alpha}^{2}}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}{\|\mathbb{E}z_{w}-\bar{z}\|^{2}},

where z¯:=1R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​zwassign¯𝑧1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤\bar{z}:=\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\mathbb{E}z_{w}, α:=BWassign𝛼𝐵𝑊\alpha:=\frac{B}{W}, Cs​α:=2−2​s​α1−2​s​αassignsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼22𝑠𝛼12𝑠𝛼C_{s\alpha}:=\frac{2-2s\alpha}{1-2s\alpha}, d:=W−1s​W−1assign𝑑𝑊1𝑠𝑊1d:=\frac{W-1}{sW-1}, and 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} is taken over the random vectors and the resampling process.

Comparing the bounds of mean-square errors given by (7) and (17), we observe that the coefficients change. When s=1𝑠1s=1, the two bounds are identical. When s>1𝑠1s>1, the coefficients in (17) smaller than those in (7) if α𝛼\alpha is sufficiently small, meaning that the inner variation and the outer variation are simultaneously reduced. The cost, however, is the capability of tolerating a smaller fraction of Byzantine workers. We will numerically depict the effect of variance reduction in Fig. 3 when discussing the main theorem.

Again, suppose zw=gwksubscript𝑧𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑤𝑘z_{w}=g_{w}^{k} as defined in (4). Then, the right-hand side of (17) contains two terms, one for inner variation and another for outer variation. Resampling can reduce the dependency on both the inner and outer variations, but cannot eliminate the inner variation. We shall see in the main theorem that, the unique coupling of SAGA and resampling in our proposed method is able to eliminate the inner variation, and hence leads to reduced learning error.

Remark 1. Above, we have discussed the connection between Lemma 1 and [30, Lemma 1]. Technically, to prove Lemma 1, we need to apply [28, Proposition 1] to guarantee the reduction of upper bound for the mean-square error as in (17). We also utilize the fact that the random vectors are independent to obtain a tight bound.

The intermediate result of Lemma 1 is the following lemma, which characterizes how the averaged mean-square error of a number of vectors depends on the inner and outer variations after resampling.

Lemma 2.

Let {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} be a subset of random vectors distributed in a normed vector space and the random vectors in {zw,w∈ℛ}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤ℛ\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{R}\} are independent. Generate from {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} a new set {z~w,w∈𝒲}subscript~𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{\tilde{z}_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\} using the resampling strategy with s𝑠s-replacement. When B<Ws𝐵𝑊𝑠B<\frac{W}{s}, there exists a set ℛ′⊆𝒲superscriptℛ′𝒲\mathcal{R}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{W} with at least W−s​B𝑊𝑠𝐵W-sB elements, such that for any w′∈ℛ′superscript𝑤′superscriptℛ′w^{\prime}\in\mathcal{R}^{\prime}, it holds that

1|ℛ′|​∑w′∈ℛ′𝔼​‖z~w′−z¯‖21superscriptℛ′subscriptsuperscript𝑤′superscriptℛ′𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~𝑧superscript𝑤′¯𝑧2\displaystyle\frac{1}{|\mathcal{R^{\prime}}|}\sum_{w^{\prime}\in\mathcal{R}^{\prime}}\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{z}_{w^{\prime}}-\bar{z}\|^{2} (18)
=\displaystyle= (d+1−dR)​1R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​‖zw−𝔼​zw‖2𝑑1𝑑𝑅1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑧𝑤𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤2\displaystyle\left(d+\frac{1-d}{R}\right)\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\mathbb{E}\left\|z_{w}-\mathbb{E}z_{w}\right\|^{2}
+dR​∑w∈ℛ‖𝔼​zw−z¯‖2,𝑑𝑅subscript𝑤ℛsuperscriptnorm𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤¯𝑧2\displaystyle+\frac{d}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\left\|\mathbb{E}z_{w}-\bar{z}\right\|^{2},

where z¯:=1R​∑w∈ℛ𝔼​zwassign¯𝑧1𝑅subscript𝑤ℛ𝔼subscript𝑧𝑤\bar{z}:=\frac{1}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\mathbb{E}z_{w}, d:=W−1s​W−1assign𝑑𝑊1𝑠𝑊1d:=\frac{W-1}{sW-1}, and 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} is taken over all the randomness.

Without resampling, we have the decomposition

Let us compare the two equalities (18) and (19). The left-hand sides of (18) and (19) are the mean-square errors of {z~w′,w′∈ℛ′}subscript~𝑧superscript𝑤′superscript𝑤′superscriptℛ′\{\tilde{z}_{w^{\prime}},w^{\prime}\in\mathcal{R}^{\prime}\} and {zw,w∈ℛ}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤ℛ\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{R}\} relative to z¯¯𝑧\bar{z}, respectively. Remark 2. The proof of Lemma 2 is nontrivial. We handle the variance of resampled vectors from two aspects, namely, the mean-square error between resampled vectors and original vectors and that between original vectors and averaged vector. This enables the application of [28, Proposition 1] to the proof.

IV-C Main theorem

The following main theorem establishes the convergence property of the proposed method.

Theorem 1.

Under Assumptions 1 and 2, if the number of Byzantine workers satisfies B<W2​s𝐵𝑊2𝑠B<\frac{W}{2s} and the step size satisfies

γ≤μ2​10​J2​L2​Cs​α,𝛾𝜇210superscript𝐽2superscript𝐿2subscript𝐶𝑠𝛼\gamma\leq\frac{\mu}{2\sqrt{10}J^{2}L^{2}C_{s\alpha}},

then the iterate xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} generated by the proposed method in Algorithm 2 satisfies

𝔼​‖xk−x∗‖2≤(1−γ​μ2)k​Δ1+Δ2,𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥2superscript1𝛾𝜇2𝑘subscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|x^{k}-x^{*}\|^{2}\leq(1-\frac{\gamma\mu}{2})^{k}\Delta_{1}+\Delta_{2}, (20)

where

Δ1:=‖x0−x∗‖2−Δ2,assignsubscriptΔ1superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥0superscript𝑥2subscriptΔ2\displaystyle\Delta_{1}:=\|x^{0}-x^{*}\|^{2}-\Delta_{2}, (21)
Δ2:=5​d​Cs​α2​δ2μ2,assignsubscriptΔ25𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2superscript𝜇2\displaystyle\Delta_{2}:=\frac{5dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}}{\mu^{2}}, (22)

while α:=BWassign𝛼𝐵𝑊\alpha:=\frac{B}{W}, Cs​α:=2−2​s​α1−2​s​αassignsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼22𝑠𝛼12𝑠𝛼C_{s\alpha}:=\frac{2-2s\alpha}{1-2s\alpha}, d:=W−1s​W−1assign𝑑𝑊1𝑠𝑊1d:=\frac{W-1}{sW-1}, and 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} denote the expectation with respect to all random variables iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k} and the resampling processes.

Theorem 1 shows that the proposed method reaches a neighborhood of the optimal solution at a linear convergence rate. The asymptotic learning error Δ2=𝒪​(d​Cs​α2​δ2)subscriptΔ2𝒪𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2\Delta_{2}={\cal O}(dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}) is determined by the outer variation, rather than the inner variation. In contrast, the learning error of Byrd-SAGA is 𝒪​(Cα2​δ2)𝒪superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2superscript𝛿2{\cal O}(C_{\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}) when B<W2𝐵𝑊2B<\frac{W}{2} . For the combination of distributed SGD and geometric median (that we call as Byrd-SGD) and the combination of distributed SGD, resampling and geometric median (that we call as RS-Byrd-SGD and give a novel analysis in Theorem 3), the learning errors are 𝒪​(Cα2​σ2+Cα2​δ2)𝒪superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2superscript𝛿2{\cal O}(C_{\alpha}^{2}\sigma^{2}+C_{\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}) and 𝒪​((d+1−dR)​Cs​α2​σ2+d​Cs​α2​δ2)𝒪𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2{\cal O}((d+\frac{1-d}{R})C_{s\alpha}^{2}\sigma^{2}+dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}) when B<W2𝐵𝑊2B<\frac{W}{2} and B<W2​s𝐵𝑊2𝑠B<\frac{W}{2s}, respectively. We compare the learning errors in Table 1.

Fig. 3 shows the dependency of learning error on α:=BWassign𝛼𝐵𝑊\alpha:=\frac{B}{W} for Byrd-SAGA and the proposed method with different s𝑠s. We omit the outer variation δ2superscript𝛿2\delta^{2} in the learning errors and compare Cα2superscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼2C_{\alpha}^{2} with d​Cs​α2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2dC_{s\alpha}^{2}. The number of all workers is set as W=30𝑊30W=30, which is consistent with the setting in the numerical experiments. Observe that when α𝛼\alpha is small enough, the proposed method has smaller learning error than Byrd-SAGA. This fact depicts the advantage of resampling in reducing the outer variation and handling the non-i.i.d. data. The side-effect of resampling is the tolerance to a smaller fraction of Byzantine workers. Larger s𝑠s means tolerance to less Byzantine workers. According to the analysis, s=2𝑠2s=2 achieves satisfactory tradeoff between the learning error and the tolerable fraction of Byzantine workers. Therefore, in the numerical experiments we set s=2𝑠2s=2, which is also recommended by [28].

Note that (5) has no closed-form solution, and must be solved with iterative algorithms. Therefore, we often consider ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate geometric median, allowing the computed vector and the true geometric median has a gap of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We use a fast Weiszfeld’s algorithm [35] to compute the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate geometric median in the numerical experiments. For simplicity, in the analysis above we assume ϵ=0italic-ϵ0\epsilon=0. In the appendices, we also consider the case of ϵ≠0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\neq 0.

Remark 3. The proof of Theorem 1 is built upon Lemma 1. There is a corresponding [30, Theorem 1] to show the convergence of Byrd-SAGA without resampling. The proof of [30, Theorem 1] is based on [30, Lemma 1], whose difference with our Lemma 1 has been discussed in Section IV-B.

V Numerical Experiments

This section presents numerical experiments to demonstrate the robustness of our proposed method. We consider both convex and nonconvex distributed learning problems. For the convex problem, we focus on the softmax regression on the MNIST [36] dataset. For the nonconvex problem, we train two-layer perceptrons, in which each layer has 50 neurons and the activation function is ‘tanh’, on the MINST and COVTYPE [37] datasets. The attributes of the datasets are described in Table 2. In the i.i.d. case, we use the MNIST dataset, launch 1 central node and W=30𝑊30W=30 workers, and let the data evenly distributed across all workers. In the non-i.i.d. case, we first use the MNIST dataset, launch 1 central node and W=30𝑊30W=30 workers, and let every three workers to evenly share the data from one class. We then use the COVTYPE dataset, launch 1 central node and W=21𝑊21W=21 workers, and also let every three workers to evenly share the data from one class. The numerical experiments are conducted on a server with two Intel(R) Xeon(R) Silver 4216 CPUs and four GeForce RTX 2080 GPUs. The source codes are available at https://github.com/pengj97/Byzantine-robust-variance-reduction

V-A Benchmark methods

We compare our proposed method with several benchmarks.

Distributed SGD. The distributed SGD aggregates the received messages by returning the mean, and hence has no robustness against Byzantine attacks.

Byrd-SGD. Byrd-SGD aggregates the received messages by returning the geometric median, as shown in (6).

RS-Byrd-SGD. RS-Byrd-SGD first resamples the received messages with s𝑠s-replacement, and then aggregates the results by returning the geometric median.

Krum. Krum aggregates the received messages by returning the one that has the smallest summation of squared distances to its W−B−2𝑊𝐵2W-B-2 nearest neighbors, given by

Krum​({zw,w∈𝒲})=zw∗,Krumsubscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲subscript𝑧superscript𝑤\displaystyle\mathrm{Krum}(\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\})=z_{w^{*}},
w∗=arg⁡minw∈𝒲​∑w→w′‖zw−zw′‖2.superscript𝑤subscript𝑤𝒲subscript→𝑤superscript𝑤′superscriptnormsubscript𝑧𝑤subscript𝑧superscript𝑤′2\displaystyle w^{*}=\arg\min_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\sum_{w\rightarrow w^{\prime}}\|z_{w}-z_{w^{\prime}}\|^{2}.

Here w→w′→𝑤superscript𝑤′w\rightarrow w^{\prime} selects the indexes w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} of the W−B−2𝑊𝐵2W-B-2 nearest neighbors of zwsubscript𝑧𝑤z_{w} in {zw,w∈𝒲}subscript𝑧𝑤𝑤𝒲\{z_{w},w\in\mathcal{W}\}. Note that Krum needs to know the number of Byzantine workers in advance [18].

Byrd-SAGA. Byrd-SAGA aggregates the received messages by returning the geometric median, but the regular workers returns the corrected stochastic gradients, not the stochastic gradients in the above benchmark methods [29, 30].

RSA. RSA is based on model aggregation, not stochastic gradient aggregation in the above benchmark methods. The central node and every worker w𝑤w maintains iterates x0ksuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑘x_{0}^{k} and xwksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘x_{w}^{k}, respectively. The update rule of the central node is

x0k+1=x0k−γ⋅λ​∑w∈𝒲sign​(x0k−xwk),superscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑘⋅𝛾𝜆subscript𝑤𝒲signsuperscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘\displaystyle x_{0}^{k+1}=x_{0}^{k}-\gamma\cdot\lambda\sum_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\mathrm{sign}(x_{0}^{k}-x_{w}^{k}),

while the update rule of regular worker w∈ℛ𝑤ℛw\in\mathcal{R} is

xwk+1=xwk−γ⋅(fw,iwk′​(xwk)+λ​sign​(xwk−x0k)).superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘⋅𝛾subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘𝜆signsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥0𝑘\displaystyle x_{w}^{k+1}=x_{w}^{k}-\gamma\cdot\left(f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x_{w}^{k})+\lambda\mathrm{sign}(x_{w}^{k}-x_{0}^{k})\right).

Here signsign\mathrm{sign} is the element-wise sign function and λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 is the penalty parameter [25].

In the numerical experiments, the batch size is 32. When using resampling, we set s=2𝑠2s=2 by default. All parameters in the benchmark methods are hand-tuned to the best.

V-B Byzantine attacks

We consider the following Byzantine attacks.

Sign-flipping attacks. Every Byzantine worker w∈ℬ𝑤ℬw\in\mathcal{B} computes its true message v^wksuperscriptsubscript^𝑣𝑤𝑘\hat{v}_{w}^{k}, and then sends vwk=c​v^wksuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript^𝑣𝑤𝑘v_{w}^{k}=c\hat{v}_{w}^{k} to the central node. Here we set c=−5𝑐5c=-5.

Gaussian attacks. Every Byzantine worker w∈ℬ𝑤ℬw\in\mathcal{B} sends message vwksuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑤𝑘v_{w}^{k}, whose elements follow Gaussian distribution 𝒩​(0,10000)𝒩010000\mathcal{N}(0,10000), to the central node.

Sample-duplicating attacks. The Byzantine workers collude to choose a specific regular worker, and duplicate its message at every time. This amounts to that the Byzantine workers duplicate the data samples of the chosen regular worker. The sample-duplicating attacks are applied in the non-i.i.d. case.

V-C Softmax regression in the i.i.d. case

We carry out numerical experiments in softmax regression on the MNIST dataset. The step size of our proposed method is γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5. When there exist Byzantine attacks, we uniformly randomly select B=6𝐵6B=6 Byzantine workers.

Without Byzantine attacks. When there exist no Byzantine attacks, all the methods are able to achieve satisfactory classification accuracies, as illustrated in Fig. 4.

Sign-flipping attacks. As depicted in Fig. 5, the distributed SGD is vulnerable and fails under the sign-flipping attacks. The other methods all perform well.

Gaussian attacks. The results of Gaussian attacks are shown in Fig. 6. The distributed SGD also fails, while the other methods have robustness to Gaussian attacks.

V-D Softmax regression in the non-i.i.d. case

Sample-duplicating attacks. We choose B=6𝐵6B=6 workers that originally share the samples of two classes as Byzantine workers. Therefore, these two classes essentially disappear under the sample-duplicating attacks, such that the best possible accuracy is 0.8. For the regular worker that is chosen to be duplicated, its class now has 9 workers out of the total W=30𝑊30W=30. The step size of our proposed method is γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5. As shown in Fig. 7, our proposed method is able to achieve the classification accuracy of around 0.73. RS-Byrd-SGD also demonstrates robustness since the resampling strategy helps reduce the impact of both inner and outer variations. However, as we have shown in the theoretical analysis, solely using resampling is unable to fully eliminate the inner variation. In contrast, the proposed method introduces SAGA to address this issue, yielding enhanced classification accuracy. RSA works well since it is developed to handle the non-i.i.d. case. The other Byzantine-robust methods, Byrd-SGD, Krum and Byrd-SAGA, all show degraded performance since they are essentially designed for distributed i.i.d. data.

Impact of the fraction of Byzantine workers α𝛼\alpha. Theorem 1 and Fig. 3 demonstrate that the learning error of the proposed method is monotonically increasing when the fraction of Byzantine workers α𝛼\alpha increases. This theoretical result is validated by Fig. 8. The other experimental settings are the same as those in Fig. 7. The classification accuracies of all the methods degrade when α𝛼\alpha increases. Compared to other benchmark methods, our proposed method is comparatively insensitive to the variation of α𝛼\alpha.

Impact of the resampling size s𝑠s. Theorem 1 and Fig. 3 also shows that the learning error of the proposed method is dependent on the resampling size s𝑠s. Fig. 9 depicts how the classification accuracies vary with respect to different s𝑠s. The other experimental settings are the same as those in Fig. 7. When s=1𝑠1s=1, our proposed method degenerates to Byrd-SAGA, which is not Byzantine-robust in the non-i.i.d. case. When s=3𝑠3s=3 and s=4𝑠4s=4, for these particular attacks, the proposed method still performs well, although the fraction of Byzantine workers α=15𝛼15\alpha=\frac{1}{5} exceeds the theoretically tolerable bound 12​s12𝑠\frac{1}{2s}.

V-E Neural network training in the non-i.i.d. case

Sample-duplicating attacks on MNIST. We choose B=3𝐵3B=3 workers that originally share the samples of one class as Byzantine workers, such that the best possible accuracy is 0.9 under the sample-duplicating attacks. The step size of our proposed method is γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1. We compare Byrd-SGD, RS-Byrd-SGD, Byrd-SAGA and our proposed method in Fig. 10. Byrd-SGD fails, but Byrd-SAGA is able to attain favorable classification accuracy since the ratio of Byzantine workers is only 10%percent1010\%. Among the two methods developed for the non-i.i.d. case, our proposed method outperforms RS-Byrd-SGD. The performance gain of Byrd-SAGA over Byrd-SGD and that of the proposed method over RS-Byrd-SGD are both due to the elimination of inner variation.

Sample-duplicating attacks on COVTYPE. We choose B=3𝐵3B=3 workers that originally share the samples of one class as Byzantine workers, such that the best possible accuracy is 0.86 under the sample-duplicating attacks. The step size of our proposed method is γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1. As shown in Fig. 11, Byrd-SGD is still the worst. However, Byrd-SAGA and RS-Byrd-SGD are both remarkably outperformed by our proposed method, since the ratio of Byzantine workers is now raised to 14%percent1414\%. Therefore, eliminating the inner variation and reducing the outer variation are of particular importance as a larger portion of received messages are Byzantine.

VI Conclusions

We develop a Byzantine-robust variance-reduced method to deal with the federated learning problem with distributed non-i.i.d. data. To reduce the impact of stochastic gradient noise that hinders the resistance to Byzantine attacks, we adopt the resampling strategy and SAGA to reduce the outer variation and fully eliminate the inner variation. The variance-reduced messages are then aggregated by geometric median. Theoretical results show that the proposed method can reach a neighborhood of the optimal solution with linear convergence rate and the learning error is determined by the number of Byzantine workers. Numerical experiments demonstrate the robustness of our proposed method. In the future work, we will investigate the elimination of outer variation, and the combination of variance-reduced methods with other robust aggregation rules.

We begin with reviewing the supporting lemma.

With Lemma 2, the proof of Lemma 1 is straightforward.

+\displaystyle+ (1−1J2)​c1​Sk11superscript𝐽2subscript𝑐1superscript𝑆𝑘\displaystyle\bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{J^{2}}\bigg{)}c_{1}S^{k}

+\displaystyle+ γ2​(2γ​μ+4​c1​J)​d​Cs​α2​δ2superscript𝛾22𝛾𝜇4subscript𝑐1𝐽𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2\displaystyle\gamma^{2}\bigg{(}\frac{2}{\gamma\mu}+4c_{1}J\bigg{)}dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}

Therefore, we can bound 𝔼​Tk+1𝔼superscript𝑇𝑘1\mathbb{E}T^{k+1} by

+((1−1J2)​c1+5​γ2​μ​(d+1−dR)​Cs​α2​L2)​Sk.11superscript𝐽2subscript𝑐15𝛾2𝜇𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝐿2superscript𝑆𝑘\displaystyle+\bigg{(}\bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{J^{2}}\bigg{)}c_{1}+\frac{5\gamma}{2\mu}\bigg{(}d+\frac{1-d}{R}\bigg{)}C_{s\alpha}^{2}L^{2}\bigg{)}S^{k}.

γ​μ2<12​J2,𝛾𝜇212superscript𝐽2\displaystyle\frac{\gamma\mu}{2}<\frac{1}{2J^{2}}, (54)

and

(1−1J2)​c1+5​γ2​μ​(d+1−dR)​Cs​α2​L2≤(1−γ​μ2)​c1.11superscript𝐽2subscript𝑐15𝛾2𝜇𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝐿21𝛾𝜇2subscript𝑐1\displaystyle\bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{J^{2}}\bigg{)}c_{1}+\frac{5\gamma}{2\mu}\bigg{(}d+\frac{1-d}{R}\bigg{)}C_{s\alpha}^{2}L^{2}\leq(1-\frac{\gamma\mu}{2})c_{1}. (56)

≤\displaystyle\leq (1−γ​μ2)​‖xk−x∗‖2+(1−γ​μ2)​c1​Sk+5​γ2​μ​d​Cs​α2​δ21𝛾𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥21𝛾𝜇2subscript𝑐1superscript𝑆𝑘5𝛾2𝜇𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2\displaystyle(1-\frac{\gamma\mu}{2})\|x^{k}-x^{*}\|^{2}+(1-\frac{\gamma\mu}{2})c_{1}S^{k}+\frac{5\gamma}{2\mu}dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}

𝔼​T1k≤(1−γ​μ2)k​[T10−Δ2]+Δ2.𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑇1𝑘superscript1𝛾𝜇2𝑘delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑇10subscriptΔ2subscriptΔ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}T_{1}^{k}\leq(1-\frac{\gamma\mu}{2})^{k}\bigg{[}T_{1}^{0}-\Delta_{2}\bigg{]}+\Delta_{2}. (58)

In our derivation so far, the constraint on the step size γ𝛾\gamma (c.f. (44), (50) and (54)) is

γ≤min𝛾\displaystyle\gamma\leq\min {μ2​L2,1J2​μ,\displaystyle\bigg{\{}\frac{\mu}{2L^{2}},\frac{1}{J^{2}\mu}, (60)
μ2​10​J3/2​L2​Cs​α​(d+(1−d)/R)1/2}.\displaystyle\frac{\mu}{2\sqrt{10}J^{3/2}L^{2}C_{s\alpha}(d+(1-d)/R)^{1/2}}\bigg{\}}.

Therefore, we simply choose

Appendix C Convergence Property of RS-Byrd-SGD

Now we show that the learning error of RS-Byrd-SGD, whose update is given by

xk+1=xk−γ⋅geomed​({g~wk,w∈𝒲}),superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘⋅𝛾geomedsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲\displaystyle x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\gamma\cdot\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{\tilde{g}_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right), (62)

is in the order of 𝒪​((d+1−dR)​Cs​α2​σ2+d​Cs​α2​δ2)𝒪𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2{\cal O}((d+\frac{1-d}{R})C_{s\alpha}^{2}\sigma^{2}+dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}).

Theorem 3.

Under Assumptions 1, 2 and 3, if the number of Byzantine workers satisfies B<W2​s𝐵𝑊2𝑠B<\frac{W}{2s} and the step size satisfies

γ≤μ2​L2,𝛾𝜇2superscript𝐿2\gamma\leq\frac{\mu}{2L^{2}},

then the iterate xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} generated by RS-Byrd-SGD satisfies

𝔼​‖xk−x∗‖2≤(1−γ​μ)k​Δ1+Δ2,𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑥2superscript1𝛾𝜇𝑘subscriptΔ1subscriptΔ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|x^{k}-x^{*}\|^{2}\leq(1-\gamma\mu)^{k}\Delta_{1}+\Delta_{2}, (63)

where

Δ2:=2μ2​((d+1−dR)​Cs​α2​σ2+d​Cs​α2​δ2).assignsubscriptΔ22superscript𝜇2𝑑1𝑑𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝜎2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼2superscript𝛿2\displaystyle\Delta_{2}:=\frac{2}{\mu^{2}}\bigg{(}\bigg{(}d+\frac{1-d}{R}\bigg{)}C_{s\alpha}^{2}\sigma^{2}+dC_{s\alpha}^{2}\delta^{2}\bigg{)}. (65)

while α:=BWassign𝛼𝐵𝑊\alpha:=\frac{B}{W}, Cs​α:=2−2​s​α1−2​s​αassignsubscript𝐶𝑠𝛼22𝑠𝛼12𝑠𝛼C_{s\alpha}:=\frac{2-2s\alpha}{1-2s\alpha}, d:=W−1s​W−1assign𝑑𝑊1𝑠𝑊1d:=\frac{W-1}{sW-1}, and 𝔼𝔼\mathbb{E} denote the expectation with respect to all random variables iwksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑤𝑘i_{w}^{k} and the resampling processes. On the other hand, the iterate xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} generated by RS-Byrd-SGD with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-approximate geometric median aggregation satisfies

(66)
Proof.

For simplicity, we only prove (63). Note that inequality (45) is still true for RS-Byrd-SGD with γ<μ2​L2𝛾𝜇2superscript𝐿2\gamma<\frac{\mu}{2L^{2}}. =\displaystyle= γ2​𝔼​‖geomed​({g~wk,w∈𝒲})−f′​(xk)‖2superscript𝛾2𝔼superscriptnormgeomedsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑤𝑘𝑤𝒲superscript𝑓′superscript𝑥𝑘2\displaystyle\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}\|\mathrm{geomed}\left(\{\tilde{g}_{w}^{k},w\in\mathcal{W}\}\right)-f^{\prime}(x^{k})\|^{2}
≤\displaystyle\leq γ2((d+1−dR)Cs​α2R∑w∈ℛ𝔼∥fw,iwk′(xk)−fw′(xk)∥2\displaystyle\gamma^{2}\bigg{(}\bigg{(}d+\frac{1-d}{R}\bigg{)}\frac{C_{s\alpha}^{2}}{R}\sum_{w\in\mathcal{R}}\mathbb{E}\|f^{\prime}_{w,i_{w}^{k}}(x^{k})-f^{\prime}_{w}(x^{k})\|^{2}
